abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Air Quality Management
            Project for Bangladesh were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: importance of public support in
            environmental policy implementation. It has been shown that
            important environment related decision with large social
            implications can be executed with public support. The
            importance of working with stakeholders was stressed from
            the beginning, and this paid off. During project
            preparation, a stakeholder delegation was sent to India to
            observe how central and local governments in India are
            tackling urban air pollution, and to discuss options for
            mitigating transport emissions. It was difficult to
            understand why a non-industrial city like Dhaka, with flat
            terrain, 300,000 vehicles, and not much pronounced biomass
            burning, could be so heavily polluted. During project
            preparation, the cause was found in that many of the 50,000
            two-stroke engine three wheelers in Dhaka are: (a) using
            more than double the quantity of lubricant recommended by
            vehicle manufacturers; and (b) using straight mineral oil, a
            lubricant not intended for use in vehicles. It is not only
            the people living in the urban areas are the victim of air
            pollution the rural people particularly the poor as well are
            the direct victim of indoor air pollution. To reduce health
            cost because of indoor air pollution a multi-pronged
            approach is needed where technology and environmental
            aspects could be well taken care of.
